\underline{Majorana TR-invariant positivity:}
In the above discussion, we have considered interacting fermion models which are Majorana reflection positive under local HS transformations.
The Majorana reflection positivity puts a strong constraint on the Majorana coefficient matrix $V$. However, for a TR-invariant system, this constraint can be released and  the model can be sign-problem-free even if $V$ does not have the form defined in Eq. (\ref{eq:bilinear}). In particular, a TR-invariant HS decomposition scheme can be found to ensure that there is no sign problem in this kind of systems, as stated in the following theorem.

{\theorem  \label{theorem:symp}
$\rho_p$ is non-negative if there exist two transformation operators, $S$ and $P$, such that
\begin{eqnarray}
    \label{eq:TR_MJ} S^T V S &=&  V^{*}, \\
    \label{eq:TR_MJ_2} P V P^{-1}&=&V,
\end{eqnarray}
where $S$ is a real antisymmetric matrix satisfying $S^2=-I$ and $S^T=-S$, 
$P$ is a symmetric or antisymmetric Hermitian matrix satisfying $P^2=I$, 
and $P$ anti-commutes with $S$,  i.e., $PS =-SP$.
}

A proof of this theorem is given in SM-IV. The HS decomposition defined by Eqs. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}) and (\ref{eq:TR_MJ_2}) is a generalization of the TR-invariant decomposition used in the determinant QMC of Dirac fermions in Refs. [\onlinecite{wu2005,hands2000}]. Here $S$ can be regarded as a generalized TR transformation operator. It, combined with complex conjugation, defines an anti-unitary transformation operator $T$ satisfying $T^2=-1$. $P$ is essentially a $Z_2$ parity transformation operator.

Eq. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}) ensures that the Majorana coefficient matrix $V$ is symmetric under the 
TR transformation. But the symmetry alone do not assure $\rho_p$ to be non-negative. This is because the eigenvalues of $V$ always appear in pairs. If $\Lambda_\alpha$ is an eigenvalue of $V$, so is  $-\Lambda_\alpha$. Moreover, from Eq. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}), it can be shown that $\pm\Lambda^*_\alpha$ are also eigenvalues of $V$. If $\Lambda_\alpha$ is purely imaginary, then $\Lambda^*_\alpha = -\Lambda_\alpha$. In this case, these four eigenvalues reduce to two if $\Lambda_\alpha$ is not doubly degenerate, and $\mathrm{Tr} \exp (-\tau H_{bl})$ may not be positive semidefinite. The parity symmetry defined by Eq. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ_2}) adds an extra constraint to the Majorana coefficient matrix. It enforces the eigenvalues of $V$ to be doubly degenerate. This Kramers degeneracy assures $\mathrm{Tr} \exp (-\tau H_{bl})>0$.

\underline{Majorana TR-invariant positivity:}
In the above discussion, we have considered interacting fermion models which are Majorana reflection positive under local HS transformations.
The Majorana reflection positivity puts a strong constraint on the Majorana coefficient matrix $V$. However, for a TR-invariant system, this constraint can be released and  the model can be sign-problem-free even if $V$ does not have the form defined in Eq. (\ref{eq:bilinear}). In particular, a TR-invariant HS decomposition scheme can be found to ensure that there is no sign problem in this kind of systems, as stated in the following theorem.

{\theorem  \label{theorem:symp}
$\rho_p$ is non-negative if there exist two transformation operators, $S$ and $P$, such that
\begin{eqnarray}
    \label{eq:TR_MJ} S^T V S &=&  V^{*}, \\
    \label{eq:TR_MJ_2} P V P^{-1}&=&V,
\end{eqnarray}
where $S$ is a real antisymmetric matrix satisfying $S^2=-I$ and $S^T=-S$, 
$P$ is a symmetric or antisymmetric Hermitian matrix satisfying $P^2=I$, 
and $P$ anti-commutes with $S$,  i.e., $PS =-SP$.
}

A proof of this theorem is given in SM-IV. The HS decomposition defined by Eqs. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}) and (\ref{eq:TR_MJ_2}) is a generalization of the TR-invariant decomposition used in the determinant QMC of Dirac fermions in Refs. [\onlinecite{wu2005,hands2000}]. Here $S$ can be regarded as a generalized TR transformation operator. It, combined with complex conjugation, defines an anti-unitary transformation operator $T$ satisfying $T^2=-1$. $P$ is essentially a $Z_2$ parity transformation operator.

Eq. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}) ensures that the Majorana coefficient matrix $V$ is symmetric under the

If $\Lambda_\alpha$ is an eigenvalue of $V$, so is  $-\Lambda_\alpha$. Moreover, from Eq. (\ref{eq:TR_MJ}), it can be shown that $\pm\Lambda^*_\alpha$ are also eigenvalues of $V$. If $\Lambda_\alpha$ is purely imaginary, then $\Lambda^*_\alpha = -\Lambda_\alpha$. In this case, these four eigenvalues reduce to two if $\Lambda_\alpha$ is not doubly degenerate, and $\mathrm{Tr} \exp (-\tau H_{bl})$ may not be positive semidefinite.
